question.text: A photon of energy <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mi>eV</mi></math> collides inelastically with a stationary hydrogen atom in the ground state. After a time interval of the order of a microsecond, another photon collides with energy of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>15</mn><mo> </mo><mi>eV</mi></math>. What will be observed by the detector?

options.text: one photon of energy <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn><mo>.2</mo><mi>eV</mi></math> and an electron having energy <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>4</mn><mo> </mo><mi>eV</mi></math>

One photon of energy <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>eV</mtext></math>and another photon of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>4</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>eV</mtext></math>

solution.text: In the time of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></math> first photon is emitted, due to second photon incident ionization of atom takes from ground state ( Like photo electric effect)
